{{unreferenced|date=November 2010}} The '''Association of Environmental Professionals''' (AEP) is a California-based [[non-profit]] organization of [[interdisciplinary]] professionals including [[environmental science]], [[resource management]], [[environmental planning]] and other professions contributing to this field. AEP is the first organization of its kind in the USA, and its influence and model have spawned numerous other regional organizations throughout the United States, as well as the separate [[National Association of Environmental Professionals]] (NAEP). Its mission is to improve the technical skills of members, and the organization is dedicated to "the enhancement, maintenance and protection of the natural and human environment". From inception in the mid-1970s the organization has been closely linked with the upkeep of the [[California Environmental Quality Act]] (CEQA), California being one of the first states to adopt a comprehensive law to govern the environmental review of public policy and project review.
==History, organization and governance==
AEP was incorporated in the State of California in 1975 and held its first organization wide meeting of members in [[Palo Alto]], California on the [[Stanford University]] campus. At that meeting the first directors and officers were elected and [[by-laws]] adopted. From then on the board of directors has met quarterly to establish governance, coordinate legislative liassion and plan annual meeting. The board represents eight geographical regions and also has three at large members.
==Publications and member activities==
AEP publishes a quarterly magazine, the [[Environmental Monitor]], which contains technical articles, [[legislative]] updates and other information useful to its members. As mentioned above the organization has developed a skilled legislative [[advocacy]] program, which is remarkable in its pursuit of clarity of language, efficient functioning of environmental review and ethical goals for its profession. AEP also provides annual recognition awards for excellence in various categories, provides members with information on career development and works to achieve standards for performance in the environmental disciplines.
The Environmental Monitor magazine is recognized throughout the interdisciplinary professions as a leading source of state of the art coverage. Articles may include topics of [[air quality]], [[Habitat (ecology)|habitat]] conservation, [[water quality]], [[archaeology]], [[urban planning]], [[acoustics]] and other technical matters; however coverage is also given to legislation, AEP activities and professional career development.
==See also==
*[[Environmental design]] *[[Environmental engineering]] *[[Environmental management]] *[[Environmental studies]] *[[European Environmental Press (EEP)]] *[[National Registry of Environmental Professionals]] (NREP) (in the US)
==External links== * [http://califaep.org/ Association of Environmental Professionals Website]

In [[machine learning]], '''Bayesian Program Synthesis (BPS)''', Bayesian Programs write (synthesize) new Bayesian programs. This is in contrast to the field of [[Probabilistic programming language|probabilistic programs]] where humans write new probabilistic (Bayesian) programs.
[[Bayesian probability|Bayesian probabilities]] is a strategy to learn distributions over Bayesian programs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/603542/ai-software-juggles-probabilities-to-learn-from-less-data/|title=AI Software Juggles Probabilities to Learn from Less Data|last=Knight|first=Will|date=|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2017-03-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
Bayesian Program Synthesis can be compared to the work on Bayesian Program Learning by Lake, Salakhutdinov, and Tenenbaum's,<ref name=":1" /> where probabilistic program components were hand-written, pre-trained on data, and then hand assembled in order to recognize handwritten characters.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lake|first=Brenden M.|last2=Salakhutdinov|first2=Ruslan|last3=Tenenbaum|first3=Joshua B.|date=2015-12-11|title=Human-level concept learning through probabilistic program induction|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/350/6266/1332|journal=Science|language=en|volume=350|issue=6266|pages=1332–1338|doi=10.1126/science.aab3050|issn=0036-8075|pmid=26659050}}</ref>
== The framework == Bayesian Program Synthesis (BPS) has been described as a framework related to and utilizing probabilistic programming. In BPS, probabilistic programs are generated that are themselves priors over a space of probabilistic programs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Technology/2017/0216/Startup-pairs-man-with-machine-to-crack-the-black-box-of-neural-networks|title=Startup pairs man with machine to crack the 'black box' of neural networks|last=Wood|first=Charlie|date=2017-02-16|work=Christian Science Monitor|access-date=2017-03-04|issn=0882-7729}}</ref> This strategy allows more automatic synthesis of new programs via inference and is achieved by the composition of modular component programs.
The modularity in BPS allows inference to work on and test smaller probabilistic programs before being integrated into a larger model.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://robohub.org/talking-machines-probabilistic-programming-with-ben-vigoda/|title=Talking Machines: Probabilistic programming, with Ben Vigoda {{!}} Robohub|website=robohub.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref>
Bayesian methods and models are frequently used to incorporate prior knowledge. When good prior knowledge can be incorporated into a Bayesian model, effective inference can often be performed with much less data.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/02/ais-factions-get-feisty-really-theyre-team/|title=AI’s Factions Get Feisty. But Really, They’re All on the Same Team|last=Metz|first=Cade|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-03-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
This framework can be also be contrasted with the family of automated [[program synthesis]] fields, including program synthesis, [[programming by example]], and [[programming by demonstration]]. The goal in such fields is to find the best program that satisfies some constraint. In program synthesis, for instance, verification of logical constraints reduce the state space of possible programs, allowing more efficient search to find an optimal program. Bayesian Program Synthesis differs both in that the constraints are probabilistic and the output is itself a distribution over programs that can be further refined.<ref name=":0" />
== See also == * [[Probabilistic programming language|Probabilistic Programming Language]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * Commentary on BPS by [[David Garrity]]: [http://www.bnn.ca/video/artificial-intelligence-to-see-significant-progress-in-2017-gva~1082352 Artificial Intelligence to see Significant Progress in 2017]

revision.text: [[File:Spam tutorial - local blacklisting.png|thumb|right|220px|Screenshot of a web page of a [[Wikimedia Foundation]]project. Filing a blacklisting request]] In [[computing]], a '''blacklist''' or '''block list''' is a basic [[access control]] mechanism that allows through all elements (email addresses, users, passwords, [[URLs]], [[IP address]]es, [[domain name]]s, file [[MD5 Hash|hashes]], etc.), except those explicitly mentioned. Those items on the list are denied access. The opposite is a [[whitelist]], which means only items on the list are let through whatever gate is being used. A [[Greylisting|greylist]] contains items that are temporarily blocked (or temporarily allowed) until an additional step is performed. Blacklists can be applied at various points in a security architecture, such as a [[Host (network)|host]], [[web proxy]], [[DNS]] servers, [[email]] server, [[Firewall (computing)|firewall]], [[directory server]]s or application authentication gateways. The type of element blocked is influenced by the access control location.{{Cite book|title = Introduction to Information Security: A Strategic-Based Approach|url = https://booksì.google.com/books?id=eZBqAAAAQBAJ|publisher = Newnes|date = 2013-11-12|isbn = 9781597499729|language = en|first = Timothy|last = Shimeall|first2 = Jonathan|last2 = Spring}} DNS servers may be well-suited to block domain names, for example, but not URLs. A firewall is well-suited for blocking IP addresses, but less so for blocking malicious files or passwords. Example uses include a company that might prevent a list of software from running on its network, a school that might prevent access to a list of web sites from its computers, or a business that wants to ensure their computer users are not choosing easily guessed, poor passwords. ==Example systems to protect== Blacklists are used to protect a variety of systems in computing. The content of the blacklist is likely needs to be targeted to the type of system defended.{{Cite web|title = Domain Blacklist Ecosystem - A Case Study|url = https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/cert/2015/06/domain-blacklist-ecosystem---a-case-study.html|website = insights.sei.cmu.edu|access-date = 2016-02-04}} ===Information systems=== An information system includes end-point hosts like user machines and servers. A blacklist in this location may include certain types of software that are not allowed to run in the company environment. For example, a company might blacklist peer to peer file sharing on its systems. In addition to software, people, devices and Web sites can also be blacklisted.{{cite book|last=Rainer | first=Watson|title=Introduction to Information Systems|year=2012|publisher=Wiley Custom Learning Solutions|isbn=978-1-118-45213-4}} ===Email=== Most email providers have a [[Email spam|anti-spam]] feature that essentially blacklists certain [[email address]]es if they are deemed unwanted. How this happens is when a successful [[phishing]] attack (from an address that is forged from reliable accounts to try to recover personal information) is executed, then the email device deems the address to be spam, and proceeds to blacklist the address. An [[e-mail spam]] [[mail filter|filter]] may keep a blacklist of email addresses, any mail from which would be prevented from reaching its intended destination. It may also use sending domain names or sending IP addresses to implement a more general block. In addition to private email blacklists, there are lists that are kept for public use, examples are * China Anti-Spam Alliance http://anti-spam.org.cn/?locale=en_US * Fabel Spamsources https://mxtoolbox.com/problem/blacklist/fabelsources * [[Spam and Open Relay Blocking System]] * The DrMX Project ===Web browsing=== The goal of a blacklist in a web browser is to prevent the user from visiting a malicious or deceitful web page via filtering locally. A common web browsing blacklist is Google's [[Google Safe Browsing|Safe Browsing]], which is installed by default in Firefox, Safari, and Chrome. ===Usernames and passwords=== Blacklisting can also apply to user credentials. It is common for systems or websites to blacklist certain reserved usernames that are not allowed to be chosen by the system or website's user populations. These reserved usernames are commonly associated with built-in system administration functions. Password blacklists are very similar to username blacklists but typically contain significantly more entries than username blacklists. Password blacklists are applied to prevent users from choosing passwords that are easily guessed or are well known and could lead to unauthorized access by malicious parties. Password blacklists are deployed as an additional layer of security, usually in addition to a password policy, which sets the requirements of the password length and/or character complexity. This is because there are a significant number of password combinations that fulfill many password policies but are still easily guessed (i.e., Password123, Qwerty123). ==Distribution methods== Blacklists are distributed in a variety of ways. Some use simple [[mailing list]]s. A [[DNSBL]] is a common distribution method that leverages the [[Domain Name System|DNS]] itself. Some lists make use of [[rsync]] for high-volume exchanges of data.{{Cite web|title = Guidelines|url = http://www.surbl.org/guidelines|website = www.surbl.org|access-date = 2016-02-04}} Web-server functions may be used; either simple [[Hypertext Transfer Protocol|GET]] requests may be used or more complicated interfaces such as a [[RESTful API Modeling Language|RESTful]] API. ==Examples== * For a list of some DNS-based blacklists, see the [[Comparison of DNS blacklists]]. * Companies like [[Google]], [[Symantec]] and [[Sucuri]] keep internal blacklists of sites known to have malware and they display a warning before allowing the user to click them. * [[Content-control software]] such as [[DansGuardian]] and [[SquidGuard]] may work with a blacklist in order to block [[Uniform Resource Locator|URLs]] of sites deemed inappropriate for a work or educational environment. Such blacklists can be obtained free of charge or from commercial vendors such as [[Squidblacklist.org]]. * A [[Firewall (computing)|firewall]] or [[Intrusion detection system|IDS]] may also use a blacklist to block known hostile IP addresses and/or networks. An example for such a list would be the [[OpenBL]] project. * Many [[copy protection]] schemes include [[software blacklist]]ing. * The company [https://www.passwordrbl.com Password RBL] offers a password blacklist for Microsoft's [[Active Directory]], web sites and apps, distributed via a [[RESTful API Modeling Language|RESTful]] API. * Members of [[online auction]] sites may add other members to a personal blacklist. This means that they cannot bid on or ask questions about your auctions, nor can they use a "buy it now" function on your items. * Yet another form of list is the yellow list which is a list of email server IP addresses that send mostly good email but do send some spam. Examples include [[Yahoo]], [[Hotmail]], and [[Gmail]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} A yellow listed server is a server that should never be accidentally blacklisted. The yellow list is checked first and if listed then blacklist tests are ignored. * In [[Linux]] [[modprobe]], the blacklist modulename entry in a modprobe configuration file indicates that all of the particular [[loadable kernel module|module]]'s internal aliases are to be ignored. There are cases where two or more modules both support the same devices, or a module invalidly claims to support a device. * Many web browsers have the ability to consult anti-[[phishing]] blacklists in order to warn users who unwittingly aim to visit a [[Internet fraud|fraudulent website]]. * Many [[peer-to-peer file sharing]] programs support blacklists that block access from sites known to be owned by companies enforcing copyright. An example is the Bluetack{{cite web |url=http://www.bluetack.co.uk/forums/index.php?autocom=faq&CODE=02&qid=18 |title= B.I.S.S. Forums - FAQ - Questions about the Blocklists |work=Bluetack Internet Security Solutions |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020052855/http://www.bluetack.co.uk/forums/index.php?autocom=faq&CODE=02&qid=18 |archivedate=2008-10-20 |accessdate=2015-08-01 }} blocklist set. ==Considerations of usage== As expressed in a recent conference paper focusing on blacklists of domain names and IP addresses used for Internet security, "these lists generally do not intersect. Therefore, it appears that these lists do not converge on one set of malicious indicators."{{Cite journal|title = Blacklist Ecosystem Analysis: Spanning Jan 2012 to Jun 2014|url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2808129|publisher = ACM|journal = Proceedings of the 2nd ACM Workshop on Information Sharing and Collaborative Security|date = 2015-01-01|pages = 13–22|first = Leigh|last = Metcalf|first2 = Jonathan M.|last2 = Spring}}{{Cite book|title = Paint It Black: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Malware Blacklists|url = https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-11379-1_1|publisher = Springer International Publishing|date = 2014-09-17|isbn = 9783319113784|pages = 1–21|series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science|doi = 10.1007/978-3-319-11379-1_1|language = en|first = Marc|last = Kührer|first2 = Christian|last2 = Rossow|first3 = Thorsten|last3 = Holz|editor-first = Angelos|editor-last = Stavrou|editor-first2 = Herbert|editor-last2 = Bos|editor-first3 = Georgios|editor-last3 = Portokalidis}} This concern combined with an economic model{{Cite journal|title = Modeling malicious domain name take-down dynamics: Why eCrime pays|url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=6805779|publisher = IEEE|journal = eCrime Researchers Summit (eCRS), 2013|date = 2013-01-01|pages = 1–9|first = Jonathan M.|last = Spring}} means that, while blacklists are an essential part of network defense, they need to be used in concert with whitelists and greylists. An example would be the Adblock Plus blocklist that includes a number of features including whitelists within the blacklist by adding a prefix of two at symbols and two pipe symbols e.g. "@@||www.blocksite.com". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.squidblacklist.org/ Squidblacklist.org - Blacklists For Squid Proxy and Content Filtering Applications.] * [https://www.ipfilterX.com/ ipfilterX by Nexus23 Labs - Blocks P2P Crawlers, Malware C&C IPs, Institutions and many more.] * [https://www.openbl.org/ OpenBL.org] - abuse reporting and blacklisting * [https://adblockplus.org/en/filters#whitelist / Adblock Plus Filter Features] - Adblock blacklist / whitelist features [[Category:Computer jargon]] [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Blacklisting|Computing]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox ancient site |name = Bouldnor Cliff |native_name = |alternate_name = |image = Bouldnor.jpg |alt = |caption = [[Bouldnor Battery]] overlooking the [[Solent]]. Bouldnor Cliff lies under the water in front of the cliffs. |map_type = United Kingdom |map_alt = |map_size = |coordinates = {{coord|50|42|49|N|01|27|50|W|display=inline,title}} |location = [[Bouldnor]], Isle of Wight, United Kingdom |region = [[Solent]] |type = |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = [[Mesolithic]] |cultures = |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = |archaeologists = |condition = Submerged |ownership = |management = |public_access = |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = }}
'''Bouldnor Cliff''' is a submerged prehistoric settlement site in the [[Solent]]. The site dates from the [[Mesolithic]] era and is in approximately {{convert|11|m|yd|0}} of water just offshore of the village of [[Bouldnor]] on the [[Isle of Wight]] in the United Kingdom. The preservation of organic materials from this era that do not normally survive on dry land has made Bouldnor important to the understanding of Mesolithic Britain, and the BBC Radio 4's Making History programme described it "probably Europe's most important Mesolithic site" albeit concealed under water.
The site was first discovered by divers from the Hampshire and Wight Trust for Maritime Archaeology (now the [[Maritime Archaeology Trust]]) in 1999, when a lobster was observed discarding worked flint tools from its burrow on the seabed.<ref name=BBCAtlantis/><ref>British Archaeology, p. 31</ref> Since then, several years of fieldwork have revealed that Bouldnor was a settlement site about 8,000 years ago, at a time when lower sea levels meant that the Solent was just a river valley. The work done so far has already revealed that the technology of Mesolithic settlers was probably 2,000 years ahead of what had previously been believed.<ref name=CP>{{Citation | title = Diving into the Past| newspaper =Isle of Wight County Press | pages =14 | date=16 September 2011}}</ref>
==Site formation== Investigations suggest that during the [[Mesolithic]] era, between 8000 and 4000 BC, the western Solent was a sheltered river basin, rich in woodland and fed by a river at [[Lymington]] and drained by the [[Western Yar]] at [[Freshwater, Isle of Wight|Freshwater]].<ref name =M10>Momber, Tomalin, Scaife, Satchell & Gillespie, preface p. 10</ref> As sea levels rose, the Solent eventually flooded and the settlement area was swamped. The rising waters deposited silt and mud onto the original land surface, covering and preserving it.<ref name= BBCAtlantis>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hampshire/6928293.stm|title=Fight on to save Stone Age Atlantis|publisher=BBC| date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref>
==Discovery== Fishermen had reported recovering stone tools from the seabed of the Solent since the 1960s, but it was not until 1987 that the submerged remains of an ancient forest were discovered at Bouldnor. Later radiocarbon dating of pollen revealed this to be approximately 8,000 years old.<ref name=BA32>British Archaeology, p. 32</ref> Subsequently, regular dives revealed a submerged cliff east of [[Yarmouth, Isle of Wight|Yarmouth]] with large quantities of peat that dated to a similar period.<ref name=BA32/>
The [[Hampshire and Wight Trust for Maritime Archaeology]] began mapping the cliff face and selected four main sites of interest (named BC 1–4). It was while diving in {{convert|11|m|yd|0}} of water on BC 2 in 1999, that divers noticed a burrowing lobster discarding [[stone tool|worked flints]] from its burrow. The lobster had burrowed through thick mud deposits that had formed since the Solent flooded, and into the original surface of the cliff when the Solent was dry.<ref name=BA32/>
Since 1999, divers have excavated at Bouldnor every year. Further discoveries were made at BC 2 and BC 4, and a later a new site was discovered nearby (BC 5).<ref name=BA33>British Archaeology, p. 33</ref> The dangerous diving conditions in the fast flowing waters of the Solent make archaeological investigation particularly difficult and archaeologists have used several new techniques to make analysis of the sea bed easier. This has included 'box sampling' – collecting large areas of sea bed in metal tins to raise them to the surface and more thoroughly excavate their contents on dry land.<ref name=CP/>
==Findings== Archaeologists have discovered large quantities of burnt flints, mounds of timbers and pits dug into the ground. Wood from this era does not normally preserve well in land environments, so the quantity of wood found at Bouldnor makes the site of international importance.<ref name=BA34>British Archaeology, p. 34</ref>
Under a large mound of worked timbers at BC 5, archaeologists discovered large areas of burnt clay, burnt flint and charcoal, which has been interpreted as the floor of a living space.<ref name=BA34/> Other timbers show signs of having been extensively worked on. Some split oak suggests that particularly large structures, or possibly boats, were being constructed at the site.<ref name=BA34/> Another timber shows signs of having been fashioned as a type of [[pipe (fluid conveyance)|conduit]], which is not something that has ever been seen in Mesolithic archaeology before.<ref>{{Cite episode| title = Making History | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b010xzzp | credits = | network = BBC | station = Radio 4 | location = Southampton| airdate = 10 May 2011 | time = 3pm – 3.30pm}}</ref> Some of the worked timbers indicate technological skills that had previously only been associated with the Neolithic era, 2000 years later than Bouldnor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maritimearchaeologytrust.org/bouldnor |title=Bouldnor Cliff|publisher=Maritime Archaeology Trust|accessdate=7 August 2013}}</ref>
Burnt hazelnuts and oak charcoal have also been found at BC 5.<ref name=BA33/> Like the wood, these types of organic material do not normally survive well in dry, land based, environments.<ref name=BBCAtlantis/> A pit dug into the clay at BC 5 had been filled with burnt clay nodules, charcoal and burnt stones, which had been covered with a large piece of wood. Examining the pit walls revealed that the pit had probably been filled with hot stones on several occasions.<ref name=BA34/> Other [[trench]]es have revealed chipped wood flakes, flint knapping flakes and even wound fibres that appear to have been used as string.<ref>Momber, Tomalin, Scaife, Satchell & Gillespie, p. 81</ref> Many of the finds suggest evidence of small scale industry as well as settlement.<ref name=M10/>
The work done at Bouldnor is exhibited in the Maritime Archaeology Trust's [[Sunken Secrets]] exhibition at [[Fort Victoria (Isle of Wight)|Fort Victoria]] on the Isle of Wight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sunkensecrets.hwtma.org.uk/currentexhibitions|title=Sunken Secrets – Current Exhibitions|accessdate=7 August 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427105202/http://sunkensecrets.hwtma.org.uk/currentexhibitions#|archive-date=27 April 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===International trade=== Research published in 2015 has identified wheat DNA at the site. As this wheat is of a type not native to Britain, it suggests the possibility of trade with Europe much earlier than had previously been supposed by archaeologists.<ref name="Balter 2015">{{cite web|last1=Balter|first1=Michael|title=DNA recovered from underwater British site may rewrite history of farming in Europe.|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/archaeology/2015/02/dna-recovered-underwater-british-site-may-rewrite-history-farming-europe?intcmp=highwire|publisher=Science|accessdate=16 March 2015}}</ref> This claim was questioned and it was suggested that the wheat DNA was too pristine and probably represents contamination.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ancient DNA dispute raises questions about wheat trade in prehistoric Britain|url = http://www.nature.com/news/ancient-dna-dispute-raises-questions-about-wheat-trade-in-prehistoric-britain-1.18702|website = Nature News & Comment|accessdate = 2015-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Contesting the presence of wheat in the British Isles 8,000 years ago by assessing ancient DNA authenticity from low-coverage data|url = http://elifesciences.org/content/4/e10005|journal = eLife|date = 2015-11-03|issn = 2050-084X|pmc = 4629168|pmid = 26525598|pages = e10005|volume = 4|doi = 10.7554/eLife.10005|first = Clemens L.|last = Weiß|first2 = Michael|last2 = Dannemann|first3 = Kay|last3 = Prüfer|first4 = Hernán A.|last4 = Burbano}}</ref> However, the original authors published a response to this contested point.<ref name="Kistler 2015">{{Cite biorxiv |title = Thermal age, cytosine deamination and the veracity of 8,000 year old wheat DNA from sediments|biorxiv = 032060}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite book|authors= G. Momber, D. Tomalin, R. Scaife, J. Satchell & J. Gillespie|title=Mesolthic occupation at Bouldnor Cliff and the submerged prehistoric landscapes of the Solent|year=2011|publisher=The Council for British Archaeology|isbn=978-1-902771-84-7}} *{{cite journal |authors=Momber. G, Satchell, J. & Gillespie, J. |date= 2011|title=Bouldnor Cliff |journal=British Archaeology |volume= |series= |issue= November – December 2011 |pages=30–35 |publisher=Council for British Archaeology |location= York|issn= 1357-4442}}
==External links== *[http://www.maritimearchaeologytrust.org/bouldnor Bouldnor Cliff] The Maritime Archaeology Trust’s information on Bouldnor Cliff *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-12244964 The moment Britain became an island] BBC news article with video of HWTMA archaeologists diving on Bouldnor Cliff
